name: Delete CHOP
description: The Delete CHOP removes entire channels and/or individual samples of its input.
summary: The Delete CHOP removes entire channels and/or individual samples of its input.

parameters.name: Delete Channels
parameters.label: Delete Channels
parameters.description:
From Derivative
		
		
		
		
		Jump to navigation
		Jump to search
		
The Delete  removes entire channels and/or individual samples of its input. 		
For deleting channels, on the Channels page, you can specify which channels to delete by channel name or a channel number range. A second method deletes channels using a value range to select channels whose values are all within a range. The third method deletes constant-valued channels. An option selects whether to delete or retain the matched channels.			
For deleting individual samples (i.e. no channels are deleted), on the Samples page you can delete, for example, only the samples whose value is below 0, which will shorten the length of the . 			
In CHOPs with two or more channels, one or more "compare" channels are used to determine which samples are to be deleted. By default it uses the first channel to compare against. Deleting a sample at a certain index deletes a value for all the channels. If there are 4 channels, red, green, blue, alpha and you specify alpha as the "compare" channel, you can delete all the samples with an alpha of 0. If a  is 3 channels with an X,Y,Z position, you can delete all samples where the XYZ length is below a threshold.			
This is useful, for example, for thinning your data before sending a  to a Geometry component for instancing. 			
When all the samples are deleted, the  will keep one sample for all channels and will have a length of one sample. When this happens, if you have an Info  attached to the Delete , it's 			
See also Splice CHOP, Select CHOP, Trim CHOP
deleteCHOP_Class

Contents
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 





  delchannels - Toggle to enable channel deleting.


		
  discard -  - Determines whether the scoped channels should be deleted or retained:

 scoped - The scoped channels are deleted. The rest are output. nonscoped - The scoped channels are output. The rest are deleted.
		
  select -  - How to select channels - , or By  index.

 byname - bynum -
		
  delscope - Enter a scope pattern here to specify the names of channels to delete or extract. You do this by specifying a scope pattern, as detailed in Pattern Matching.	
The default scope pattern t* will scope the translation channels: tx, ty, and tz , or any other channel whose name starts with t.

		
  selnumbers - The indices of the channels to delete or extract. - See possible number patterns below.


		
  chanvalue -  - Chooses the type of value range selection:

 off - Don't perform range selection. complete - All the channel's samples must be within the specified range for it to be selected. partial - At least one of the channel's samples must be in the range for it to be selected. outside - None of the channel's samples can be in the range for it to be selected.
		
  selrange -  - The lower and upper values of the range used for Range Selection.

selrange1 -selrange2 -
		
  selconst - Select channels which have the same value for all samples. These kinds of channel name patterns are used to select existing channels in an input , see Pattern Matching for details.	
Also these kinds of channel number patterns can be used to select existing channels in an input :			

 0 1 4 - Matches the first, second and fifth channel.
 [0-4] - Matches the first five channels.
[3-9:2] - Matches channels at indices 3,5, 7 and 9.




  delsamples - Toggle to enable sample deleting.


		
  compchans -  - How to select channels used to compare against criteria - By , by  index, by using the , or by using the .

 firstchan - lastchan - byname - bynum -
		
  compnames - Enter a scope pattern here to specify the names of channels to be used as compare channels. You do this by specifying a scope pattern, as detailed in Pattern Matching.


		
  compnums - The indices of the channels to be used as compare channels, the default being 0, the first channel. - See possible number patterns above.


		
  compmulti -  - If there is more that one compare channel, this determines how to treat the values in the compare channels before checking against the criteria:

 any - Delete the sample if any of the compare channels meets the criteria. all - Delete the sample if all the compare channels meets the criteria. add - Add all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. sub - Subtract all the compare channels from the first and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. mul - Multiply all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. div - Divide the first channel by rest of the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. avg - Find the average of all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. min - Find the minimum of all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. max - Find the maximum of all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. len - Assume all the compare channels are vectors and find their length, and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria.
		
  condition -  - Choose the criteria for the samples to be compare against:

 less - Delete if the comparing samples are below Value 1. greater - Delete if the comparing samples are above Value 1. equal - Delete if the comparing samples are equal to Value 1. notequal - Delete if the comparing samples are not equal to Value 1. inside - Delete if the comparing samples are inside the range assigned by Value 1 and Value 2. outside - Delete if the comparing samples are outside the range assigned by Value 1 and Value 2.
		
  value1 - Set a value for Value 1.


		
  inclvalue1 - Toggle the inclusivity of Value 1.


		
  value2 - Set a value for Value 2.


		
  inclvalue2 - Toggle the inclusivity of Value 2.


		
  deletecomp - Determines whether the compare channels should be deleted or retained.


		
  onesample - Leaves one sample even when all samples are deleted.





  timeslice - Turning this on forces the channels to be "Time Sliced".  A  is the time between the last cook frame and the current cook frame.



  scope - To determine which channels get affected, some CHOPs use a  string on the Common page. See Pattern Matching.



  srselect -  - Handle cases where multiple input CHOPs' sample rates are different. When Resampling occurs, the curves are interpolated according to the Interpolation Method Option, or "Linear" if the Interpolate Options are not available.

 first - Use rate of first input to resample others. max - Resample to the highest sample rate. min - Resample to the lowest sample rate. err - Doesn't accept conflicting sample rates.

  exportmethod -  - This will determine how to connect the  channel to the parameter. Refer to the Export article for more information.

 datindex - Uses the docked  table and references the channel via the index of the channel in the . datname - Uses the docked  table and references the channel via the name of the channel in the . autoname - The channel is the full destination of where to export to, such has geo1/transform1:tx.

  autoexportroot - This path points to the root node where all of the paths that exporting by Channel Name is : are relative to.



  exporttable - The  used to hold the export information when using the  Table  Methods (See above).





 -
 -

Extra Information for the Delete  can be accessed via an Info CHOP.


 -
 - Start of the  interval in samples. - Number of samples in the . - The samplerate of the channels in frames per second. - Number of channels in the . - 1 if  is  enabled, 0 otherwise. - A count of how often the export connections have been updated.
 - Number of times the operator has cooked since the process started. - Duration of the last cook in milliseconds. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the component timeline. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the absolute time. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator started cooking in the frame it was cooked. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator finished cooking in the frame it was cooked. - 1 if operator was cooked this frame. - Number of warnings in this operator if any. - Number of errors in this operator if any.
TouchDesigner Build: Latest\n2022.241402021.100002018.28070before 2018.28070
CHOPs
• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • 

An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



A CHOP outputs one or more channels, where a channel is simply a sequence of numbers (Samples), representing motion, audio, etc. Channels are passed between CHOPs in TouchDesigner networks. Channels can be Exported to Parameters.



A Time Slice is the time from the last cook frame to the current cook frame. In CHOPs it is the set of short channels that contain the CHOP channels' samples between the last and the current cook frame.



A parameter in most CHOPs that restricts which channels of that CHOP will be affected. Normally all channels of a CHOP are affected by the operator. TOPs have Channel Mask, a similar feature.



samples-per-second of a CHOP. Each CHOP in your network has a sample rate. In contrast, the overall timeline has a Frame Rate, which is the number of frames to cook and display per second, generally your monitor display frequency, default 60.



Exporting is the connection of CHOP channels to parameters of operators. The output of each exporting CHOP is one or more channels, active only while the CHOP Viewer is on. The current value of a channel can be exported to a parameter of any operator, overriding that parameter's value. See Parameter.



An Operator Family that manipulates text strings: multi-line text or tables. Multi-line text is often a python Script or GLSL Shader, but can be any multi-line text. Tables are rows and columns of cells, each containing a text string.



The location of an operator within the TouchDesigner environment, for example, /geo1/circle1, a node called circle1 in a component called geo1. The path / is called Root. This path is displayed at the top of every Pane, showing which Component's network you are currently in. To refer instead to a filesystem folder, directory, disk file or http: address, see Folder.



Every operator in TouchDesigner has a set of control Parameters that can be integer or floating point numbers, menus, binary toggles, text strings or operator paths, which determine the output of the operator.



TouchDesigner is a hierarchy of components. "root" is the top-most network in the hierarchy. The Network Path or Path for root is simply /. A typical path is /project1/moviein1.








Retrieved from "https://docs.derivative.ca/index.php?title=Delete_CHOP&oldid=24427"
		Category: CHOPs

CHOPs
• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • 

An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



A CHOP outputs one or more channels, where a channel is simply a sequence of numbers (Samples), representing motion, audio, etc. Channels are passed between CHOPs in TouchDesigner networks. Channels can be Exported to Parameters.



A Time Slice is the time from the last cook frame to the current cook frame. In CHOPs it is the set of short channels that contain the CHOP channels' samples between the last and the current cook frame.



A parameter in most CHOPs that restricts which channels of that CHOP will be affected. Normally all channels of a CHOP are affected by the operator. TOPs have Channel Mask, a similar feature.



samples-per-second of a CHOP. Each CHOP in your network has a sample rate. In contrast, the overall timeline has a Frame Rate, which is the number of frames to cook and display per second, generally your monitor display frequency, default 60.



Exporting is the connection of CHOP channels to parameters of operators. The output of each exporting CHOP is one or more channels, active only while the CHOP Viewer is on. The current value of a channel can be exported to a parameter of any operator, overriding that parameter's value. See Parameter.



An Operator Family that manipulates text strings: multi-line text or tables. Multi-line text is often a python Script or GLSL Shader, but can be any multi-line text. Tables are rows and columns of cells, each containing a text string.



The location of an operator within the TouchDesigner environment, for example, /geo1/circle1, a node called circle1 in a component called geo1. The path / is called Root. This path is displayed at the top of every Pane, showing which Component's network you are currently in. To refer instead to a filesystem folder, directory, disk file or http: address, see Folder.



Every operator in TouchDesigner has a set of control Parameters that can be integer or floating point numbers, menus, binary toggles, text strings or operator paths, which determine the output of the operator.



TouchDesigner is a hierarchy of components. "root" is the top-most network in the hierarchy. The Network Path or Path for root is simply /. A typical path is /project1/moviein1.








Retrieved from "https://docs.derivative.ca/index.php?title=Delete_CHOP&oldid=24427"

parameters.name: Delete Channels
parameters.label: Delete Channels
parameters.description: delchannels - Toggle to enable channel deleting.

parameters.name: Delete
parameters.label: Delete
parameters.description:
discard -  - Determines whether the scoped channels should be deleted or retained:

 scoped - The scoped channels are deleted. The rest are output. nonscoped - The scoped channels are output. The rest are deleted.

parameters.name: Scoped Channels
parameters.label: Scoped Channels
parameters.description: scoped - The scoped channels are deleted. The rest are output. nonscoped - The scoped channels are output. The rest are deleted.

parameters.name: Select Channels
parameters.label: Select Channels
parameters.description:
select -  - How to select channels - , or By  index.

 byname - bynum -

parameters.name: By Channel Name
parameters.label: By Channel Name
parameters.description: byname - bynum -

parameters.name: Channel Names
parameters.label: Channel Names
parameters.description:
delscope - Enter a scope pattern here to specify the names of channels to delete or extract. You do this by specifying a scope pattern, as detailed in Pattern Matching.	
The default scope pattern t* will scope the translation channels: tx, ty, and tz , or any other channel whose name starts with t.

parameters.name: Channel Numbers
parameters.label: Channel Numbers
parameters.description: selnumbers - The indices of the channels to delete or extract. - See possible number patterns below.

parameters.name: Channel Value
parameters.label: Channel Value
parameters.description:
chanvalue -  - Chooses the type of value range selection:

 off - Don't perform range selection. complete - All the channel's samples must be within the specified range for it to be selected. partial - At least one of the channel's samples must be in the range for it to be selected. outside - None of the channel's samples can be in the range for it to be selected.

parameters.name: Off
parameters.label: Off
parameters.description: off - Don't perform range selection. complete - All the channel's samples must be within the specified range for it to be selected. partial - At least one of the channel's samples must be in the range for it to be selected. outside - None of the channel's samples can be in the range for it to be selected.

parameters.name: Value Range
parameters.label: Value Range
parameters.description:
selrange -  - The lower and upper values of the range used for Range Selection.

selrange1 -selrange2 -

parameters.name: Select Constant Valued Channels
parameters.label: Select Constant Valued Channels
parameters.description:
selconst - Select channels which have the same value for all samples. These kinds of channel name patterns are used to select existing channels in an input , see Pattern Matching for details.	
Also these kinds of channel number patterns can be used to select existing channels in an input :			

 0 1 4 - Matches the first, second and fifth channel.
 [0-4] - Matches the first five channels.
[3-9:2] - Matches channels at indices 3,5, 7 and 9.

parameters.name: Delete Samples
parameters.label: Delete Samples
parameters.description: delsamples - Toggle to enable sample deleting.

parameters.name: Channels to Compare
parameters.label: Channels to Compare
parameters.description:
compchans -  - How to select channels used to compare against criteria - By , by  index, by using the , or by using the .

 firstchan - lastchan - byname - bynum -

parameters.name: Use First Channel
parameters.label: Use First Channel
parameters.description: firstchan - lastchan - byname - bynum -

parameters.name: Channel Names
parameters.label: Channel Names
parameters.description: compnames - Enter a scope pattern here to specify the names of channels to be used as compare channels. You do this by specifying a scope pattern, as detailed in Pattern Matching.

parameters.name: Channel Numbers
parameters.label: Channel Numbers
parameters.description: compnums - The indices of the channels to be used as compare channels, the default being 0, the first channel. - See possible number patterns above.

parameters.name: Multi-Compare Channels
parameters.label: Multi-Compare Channels
parameters.description:
compmulti -  - If there is more that one compare channel, this determines how to treat the values in the compare channels before checking against the criteria:

 any - Delete the sample if any of the compare channels meets the criteria. all - Delete the sample if all the compare channels meets the criteria. add - Add all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. sub - Subtract all the compare channels from the first and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. mul - Multiply all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. div - Divide the first channel by rest of the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. avg - Find the average of all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. min - Find the minimum of all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. max - Find the maximum of all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. len - Assume all the compare channels are vectors and find their length, and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria.

parameters.name: Any Chan in Range
parameters.label: Any Chan in Range
parameters.description: any - Delete the sample if any of the compare channels meets the criteria. all - Delete the sample if all the compare channels meets the criteria. add - Add all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. sub - Subtract all the compare channels from the first and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. mul - Multiply all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. div - Divide the first channel by rest of the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. avg - Find the average of all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. min - Find the minimum of all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. max - Find the maximum of all the compare channels and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria. len - Assume all the compare channels are vectors and find their length, and delete the sample if the result meets the criteria.

parameters.name: Delete Condition
parameters.label: Delete Condition
parameters.description:
condition -  - Choose the criteria for the samples to be compare against:

 less - Delete if the comparing samples are below Value 1. greater - Delete if the comparing samples are above Value 1. equal - Delete if the comparing samples are equal to Value 1. notequal - Delete if the comparing samples are not equal to Value 1. inside - Delete if the comparing samples are inside the range assigned by Value 1 and Value 2. outside - Delete if the comparing samples are outside the range assigned by Value 1 and Value 2.

parameters.name: Less Than Value 1
parameters.label: Less Than Value 1
parameters.description: less - Delete if the comparing samples are below Value 1. greater - Delete if the comparing samples are above Value 1. equal - Delete if the comparing samples are equal to Value 1. notequal - Delete if the comparing samples are not equal to Value 1. inside - Delete if the comparing samples are inside the range assigned by Value 1 and Value 2. outside - Delete if the comparing samples are outside the range assigned by Value 1 and Value 2.

parameters.name: Value 1
parameters.label: Value 1
parameters.description: value1 - Set a value for Value 1.

parameters.name: Include Value 1
parameters.label: Include Value 1
parameters.description: inclvalue1 - Toggle the inclusivity of Value 1.

parameters.name: Value 2
parameters.label: Value 2
parameters.description: value2 - Set a value for Value 2.

parameters.name: Include Value 2
parameters.label: Include Value 2
parameters.description: inclvalue2 - Toggle the inclusivity of Value 2.

parameters.name: Delete Compare Channels
parameters.label: Delete Compare Channels
parameters.description: deletecomp - Determines whether the compare channels should be deleted or retained.

parameters.name: One Sample if All Deleted
parameters.label: One Sample if All Deleted
parameters.description: onesample - Leaves one sample even when all samples are deleted.

parameters.name: Time Slice
parameters.label: Time Slice
parameters.description: timeslice - Turning this on forces the channels to be "Time Sliced".  A  is the time between the last cook frame and the current cook frame.

parameters.name: Scope
parameters.label: Scope
parameters.description: scope - To determine which channels get affected, some CHOPs use a  string on the Common page. See Pattern Matching.

parameters.name: Sample Rate Match
parameters.label: Sample Rate Match
parameters.description:
srselect -  - Handle cases where multiple input CHOPs' sample rates are different. When Resampling occurs, the curves are interpolated according to the Interpolation Method Option, or "Linear" if the Interpolate Options are not available.

 first - Use rate of first input to resample others. max - Resample to the highest sample rate. min - Resample to the lowest sample rate. err - Doesn't accept conflicting sample rates.

parameters.name: Resample At First Input's Rate
parameters.label: Resample At First Input's Rate
parameters.description: first - Use rate of first input to resample others. max - Resample to the highest sample rate. min - Resample to the lowest sample rate. err - Doesn't accept conflicting sample rates.

parameters.name: Export Method
parameters.label: Export Method
parameters.description:
exportmethod -  - This will determine how to connect the  channel to the parameter. Refer to the Export article for more information.

 datindex - Uses the docked  table and references the channel via the index of the channel in the . datname - Uses the docked  table and references the channel via the name of the channel in the . autoname - The channel is the full destination of where to export to, such has geo1/transform1:tx.

parameters.name: DAT Table by Index
parameters.label: DAT Table by Index
parameters.description: datindex - Uses the docked  table and references the channel via the index of the channel in the . datname - Uses the docked  table and references the channel via the name of the channel in the . autoname - The channel is the full destination of where to export to, such has geo1/transform1:tx.

parameters.name: Export Root
parameters.label: Export Root
parameters.description: autoexportroot - This path points to the root node where all of the paths that exporting by Channel Name is : are relative to.

parameters.name: Export Table
parameters.label: Export Table
parameters.description: exporttable - The  used to hold the export information when using the  Table  Methods (See above).
